Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: G Protein Regulation of the Actin Cytoskeleton in the Cleavage Stage Embryo

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cell division is a fundamental process for virtually all living systems. The generation of two identical daughter cells requires not only that each cell receives an equal complement of genetic material (DNA) but also that the other contents of the cell be divided equally. The process of physically separating the two daughter cells is known as cytokinesis, and this process involves a contractile ring that physically constricts the cell and splits it in two. Cytokinesis utilizes many of the same mechanisms that are used to regulate cell shape change during migration. Cell shape is dependent on a dynamic structure (the cytoskeleton) that is comprised primarily of the protein actin, and whose behavior is regulated by a number of small signaling molecules. Several conflicting models have been proposed to explain how these small molecules interact to control the cytoskeleton, but the explanatory power of these models has not been clearly established. This project will investigate the regulation of the cytoskeleton by these small signaling molecules and help to clarify the mechanisms by which they function.This research will provide training and educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, with a concerted effort to recruit underrepresented minorities including Native American Indian and Hispanic students. Outreach into high schools will also be performed with the intent to generate in students a long-term interest in science.

In this project, a toolbox of molecular and pharmacological reagents will be combined with biophysical measurements and high-resolution light and electron microscopy to examine how the G proteins Rho, Rac, and Cdc42 coordinate cytokinesis-related shape change in large embryonic cells. Aims 1 and 2 will use a combination of live cell imaging and biophysical analyses to determine what elements of Rac and Cdc42 signaling antagonize Rho-dependent cytokinesis. Aim 3 will take advantage of a unique preparation of the contractile ring to both define its 3D structure and determine how the different elements of Rho signaling contribute to its assembly and function. The results of these studies will advance knowledge in the field of animal cell division research by extending our understanding of the precise 3D architecture of actin and myosin II in the contractile ring that drives cytokinesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction: Cytokinesis is the final step of cell division whereby the two daughter cells are physically partitioned. In animal cells, the driving force for cytokinesis is provided by the contractile ring, a transient structure comprised of actin and myosin II which generates tension at the cell equator to split the cell in two. The master regulator of contractile ring assembly is the small G protein Rho, which together with Rac and Cdc42 regulate cytoskeletal dynamics in nonmuscle animal cells. In this project, we employed the eggs and early embryos of sea urchins as a model system to understand how these regulatory switches inhibited or promoted contractile ring assembly, as well as to define at the nanoscale-level the organization of the contractile ring. 

 Intellectual Merit: We applied a combination of live cell and high-resolution light and electron microscopy to address these questions. Our results found that Rac directly antagonizes cytokinesis through the activation of Ar2/3-nucleated branched actin networks. Cdc42 also antagonizes cytokinesis, but as development proceeds, Cdc42 appears to be required for cell division as embryonic cells polarize and organize into an epithelia. Moreover, we found that Cdc42 is specifically required for the motility of a population of mesodermal cells later in embryogenesis. Using super resolution and transmission electron microscopy, we found that that myosin II organizes into a highly organized array of concatenated filaments from pool of loosely organized foci of myosin II, septin and anillin, which resemble in form and composition the precursor nodes characterized in fission yeast but until now have not been observed in any other organism. Lastly, we identified several factors that regulate the formation of the polar lobe, an actomyosin constriction that occurs during the early development of several phyla but whose functional relationship to the contractile ring has been unknown.

 

 Broader Impacts: This project was a collaboration between an investigator at a public, minority-serving, research university (New Mexico State University) and a private, small liberal arts college (Dickinson College). In addition to presenting together at conferences, the PI?s and their students worked together during the summer months at the University of Washington?s Friday Harbor Laboratories. The project supported the work of three female URM Ph.D. students, three female M.S. students, and over a dozen undergraduate students (including many under-represented minority students) between the two institutions. In addition to the training they received in the laboratory, students presented this research at conferences, and served as co-authors on peer-reviewed publications. The project has also supported educational endeavors at both the undergraduate and graduate levels, including a new undergraduate research course entitled Bio-Imaging at Dickinson and a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) course at NMSU. Lastly, the NMSU PI has served as a co-directed for the Logan Science Journalism Program at the Marine Biological Laboratory, where working science writers perform inquiry-based experiments related to the award.

 Summary:  The lines of experimentation supported by this award have revealed new insights into how the contractile ring is both spatially regulated and assembled from a pool of precursor contractile proteins in large spherical cells. These efforts also supported the broader participation of underrepresented groups in cell and developmental biology research, and helped increase scientific literacy by providing working science journalists hands-on experiences in the process of scientific inquiry.
